plastic.harm: Plastic breaks down into microplastics that pollute soil, water, and enter the food chain. It releases toxic chemicals during degradation and harms marine life.
plastic.emissions: Produces greenhouse gases during production and when burned.
plastic.recycling_fact: Most plastic can be recycled, but globally only about 9% actually is.
tips: Avoid single-use plastic products whenever possible.
Carry reusable bottles, bags, and containers.
Properly clean and sort plastic before recycling to avoid contamination.
plastic.description: Plastic waste is one of the most persistent pollutants and remains in the environment for centuries.

glass.harm: Glass does not break down naturally and can cause physical harm to humans and wildlife. Glass production requires high energy and emits CO₂.
glass.recycling_fact: Glass is 100% recyclable and can be recycled endlessly without losing quality.
tips: Reuse jars and bottles for storage or decoration.
Do not mix broken glass with regular recycling unless your city accepts it.
Return glass bottles to collection centers where available.
glass.description: Though recyclable, glass has an extremely long decomposition time and high carbon footprint during manufacturing.

paper.harm: Paper waste is biodegradable but contributes to deforestation and increases landfill volume when not recycled.
paper.emissions: Lower emissions than plastic or metal, but still significant during production.
paper.recycling_fact: Recycling 1 ton of paper saves 17 trees and 7,000 gallons of water.
tips: Reuse old paper for notes or crafts before discarding.
Buy recycled paper products whenever possible.
paper.description: Paper decomposes quickly but its production requires trees, water, and energy.

metal.harm: Mining for metals damages ecosystems, causes land erosion, and consumes large amounts of energy. Improper disposal can lead to rust contamination.
metal.emissions: High energy usage and air pollution during metal extraction and smelting.
metal.recycling_fact: Recycling aluminum saves up to 95% of the energy required to produce new aluminum.
tips: Always recycle cans, tins, and metal containers.
Reuse metal jars or boxes for storage.
Support brands that use recycled metal packaging.
metal.description: Metal is long-lasting and valuable, and recycling it drastically reduces environmental damage.

cardboard.harm: Cardboard decomposes naturally, but when left in landfills without oxygen, it releases methane—a potent greenhouse gas.
cardboard.emissions: Moderate during production but low during recycling.
cardboard.recycling_fact: Cardboard can be recycled up to 7 times before fibers weaken.
tips: Flatten boxes before recycling to save space.
Keep cardboard dry and clean—wet cardboard cannot be recycled.
Reuse boxes for storage, crafts, or shipping before discarding.
cardboard.description: Cardboard is one of the most eco-friendly packaging materials due to high recyclability.
